header.title: Elelogap: The Spirit of the Waters

central_thesis: The book introduces Elelogap, a powerful Water Spirit from the True Grimoire, detailing methods for establishing an animist working relationship to enhance magical operations, personal health, emotional well-being, and connections with other spirits and deities. It emphasizes a respectful, ongoing alliance rather than coercive binding.

structure_content.chapter_title: Elelogap: the Spirit of the Waters
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces Elelogap as a significant spirit from the True Grimoire and the Key of Solomon, exploring its etymological roots related to 'elevated' and 'praised' (connecting to Greek Eleleu, Hebrew Hallelujah, and Helel). It identifies Elelogap with 'Gaap' from other grimoires, a King of Water, and posits a descent from the Egyptian god Hapi, the god of the Nile and Celestial Waters. The chapter translates Elelogap's name as 'the Higher Waters' or 'Holy Water' and notes its unique hierarchical position under two deputies (Agliarept and Tarihimal) from different Chiefs (Lucifer and Belzebuth), indicating complex, wide-ranging powers.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Nature and Workings of Elelogap
structure_content.summary: This section explains Elelogap's role within an elemental classification of spirits, identifying it as a powerful Undine (Water Elemental). It highlights the enormous advantage of an alliance with such a 'Governor' for a practical magician, benefiting various types of magic, alchemy, ritual, purification baths, and ink-making. The core principle involves adapting magical work so Elelogap actively assists in any water-related occult practice, fostering an ongoing relationship. This work is said to positively impact emotional life due to water's astrological connection to emotions, and improve health (beginning with simple practices like drinking imbued water).

This chapter explores the symbolic and operative significance of different types of water based on ancient sources, particularly the Magical Papyri. It categorizes rainwater as 'Heavenly' (for celestial gods, Holy Water, healing), spring water for the Underworld (ancestral spirits, gates between worlds), river water for powerful gods like Osiris and Serapis (and connecting to the Greek Underworld rivers), and seawater for Gods of the Earth (terrestrial and natural world). The text also describes making artificial seawater and notes the complex role of salt in magical workings, especially concerning spirits of the dead.

This section provides detailed instructions for constructing and consecrating two primary water-related magical instruments from the True Grimoire: the asperser (water vessel) and the aspergillus (sprinkler). Both are to be made or consecrated during Mercury's day and hour with a crescent Moon. Specific inscriptions/names (COPH-NIA, FALUTLI, AORMUZDI, NU-HAD, BABALON) are provided for the asperser. The aspergillus is to be made from mint, marjoram, and rosemary. Ritual blessings and charges for the water and instruments are given, involving names like Nuit, Hadit, Ra-Hoor-Khuit, and an invocation to Elelogap to impart purifying power. The consecration also includes perfuming with aromatics (aloes wood, frankincense, mace) and specific prayers.

This chapter broadens the discussion to Water Elementals beyond Elelogap, referencing Orpheus's Nereides and the Comte de Gabalis's Undines/Nymphs. It describes various classes of Nymphs (Nereides, Naiades, Oceanides) their characteristics, associations with different water bodies, offerings (milk, honey, oil), and mythological figures like Nereus, Oceanus, Tethys, and Proteus, often with prophetic or shape-shifting powers. Orphic Hymns dedicated to these water deities are provided as examples for devotional practice. It highlights the importance of knowing spirit names for magical action and emphasizes the animistic connection between these ancient water spirits and later grimoire traditions.
This section is listed in the table of contents but no content is provided in the OCR text.

This concluding section contextualizes the booklet within the 'Spirit Work Series,' aiming to introduce individual spirits of the True Grimoire. It argues that the True Grimoire represents a surviving link to an ancient, pre-Christian animist tradition, distinct from common Western magical views that often demonize or bind spirits. The series advocates a respectful, alliance-based approach, drawing parallels with ancient Egyptian, Greek, and Gnostic traditions, and emphasizes personal transformation as a key outcome of working with these spirits.

key_concepts.definition: A mighty Water Spirit from the True Grimoire, governing all matters concerning water. Identified with 'Gaap' and linked to the Egyptian god Hapi. Holds a unique, powerful position in the grimoire hierarchy, supervising lesser water spirits and assisting in various magical workings related to water, health, and emotions.

A foundational text in Western Esotericism, presented here as containing a potent, pre-Christian animist system of evocation, often obscured by later demonization. The 'Spirit Work Series' aims to re-contextualize and make accessible its inherent magical system.

A method of engaging with spirits based on respect, alliance, and mutual benefit, contrasting with coercive or binding practices. This approach encourages attunement with spirits' natures and facilitates personal transformation.

A traditional system categorizing spirits by their elemental association (Fire/Salamanders, Air/Sylphs, Water/Undines, Earth/Gnomes). Elelogap is identified as a powerful Undine, a Governor among Water Elementals.

Various sources of water used in magic, each with distinct symbolic and operative properties: rainwater (celestial, healing, Holy Water), spring water (Underworld, ancestral spirits), river water (powerful gods, Underworld connections), and seawater (terrestrial gods, nature, creation).

Key ritual tools for water magic. The asperser is a dedicated vessel for holding magical water, and the aspergillus is a sprinkler, typically made of specific herbs (mint, marjoram, rosemary). Both are consecrated to Elelogap for use in purification and other water-related operations.

General term for various female water spirits and deities (including Undines, Nereides, Oceanides, Naiades) found in ancient Greek mythology and folklore. They are associated with different water bodies and are considered followers of Elelogap, often possessing prophetic or shape-shifting qualities.

practical_system.description: The book presents a practical, animist system for working with Elelogap and other water elementals, emphasizing the cultivation of an ongoing, respectful alliance rather than mere coercion. It integrates daily practices with formal rituals to imbue all water-related activities with magical potency and foster personal transformation.
tools: Pure water: rainwater (preferred for Celestial/Holy Water), spring water (for Underworld), river water (for specific deities/Underworld regions), seawater (for Earth gods/Nature), or ritually prepared artificial seawater.

Asperser: A dedicated vessel (goblet, pot, ladle) for water, made of brass, earthenware, or varnished lead, engraved/painted with specific names/sigils, consecrated on Mercury's day/hour during a crescent Moon.
Aspergillus: A sprinkler made from sprigs of mint, marjoram, and rosemary, bound with new white cord (or religious cord), consecrated simultaneously with the asperser.
Sieve: For filtering water, lined with clean muslin or other cloth.
Storage Containers: Preferably large, with removable covers for access and personal connection to the water.
Censer: For burning incense during consecrations and offerings.

Aromatics: Aloes wood, frankincense, mace (for instrument consecration); Myrrh (for Nereus hymn); Storax (for Proteus hymn); Frankincense and Manna (for Tethys hymn); Frankincense and Myrrh (for Elelogap invocation).
rituals: Daily drinking of pure water imbued with Elelogap's presence and intention to know the spirit better.
Incorporating Elelogap's assistance in all magical work involving water, with specific invocations for purification or cleaning ritual items.
Performing ritual baths (ablutions) with invocations to Elelogap, either as standalone practice or prior to other magical operations.

Consecration of water-related magical instruments (asperser, aspergillus) through a multi-stage process involving blessings, charging with specific names (Nuit, Hadit, Ra-Hoor-Khuit, COPH-NIA, FALUTLI, AORMUZDI, NU-HAD, BABALON), perfuming with aromatics, and reciting the Orison of the Instrument.

Employing water for Gnosis and Illumination through sacred spring visits, invocations, or ritual immersion/dousing (e.g., dipping head seven times in water, a large bowl, or dousing with cupped hands) combined with ritual preparation and invocation.
Offering pure rainwater to various spirits as a form of communication and rapport building.
Reciting Orphic Hymns to water deities (Nereus, Oceanus, Tethys, Proteus, Nereides) accompanied by specific incense offerings to establish connection and invoke their aid.
Performing the 'Prayer of the Undines' to empathize and attune with water elementals, fostering trust rather than compulsion.
Making a specific 'Invocation of Elelogap' with offerings of clear refreshing water, frankincense, and myrrh to gain dominion over water and connect with ancient powers.

relevant_quotes.text: For the assistance of a Mighty Spirit of the Waters: in contacting the Celestial and Terrestrial Gods, the Chiefs of the Underworld and the spirits of the dead. For invoking in conjurations of lesser spirits of the Waters; for assistance in working with herbs, magical baths and washes, visions and clairvoyance; to enhance your emotional nature, to improve your health and your life.
Elelogap is a spirit of the True Grimoire, and of the Key of Solomon delivered by Armadel. The first part of the spirit's name comes from ancient roots meaning 'elevated, exalted, high, praised'.
'Rainwater if you are calling upon heavenly gods, seawater if gods of the earth. river water if Osiris or Sarapis. springwater if the dead'.

The simplest way to begin this work is by drinking water. This is something many Westerners do not do enough of anyway, with consequences for their health and well being they disregard at their peril.

'I bless and sanctify this water in the names of Nuit, Hadit and Ra-Hoor-Khuit! Amen.' Then charge the water as follows: 'In the names COPH-NIA, FALUTLI, AORMUZDI, NU-HAD (&/or BABALON), and the potent chiefs Agliarept and Tarihimal, I ask thee ELELOGAP to impart purifying power to this water in the rites of Magick.'

The Elemental Prayers are fairly well known to modern occultists from two sources. Primarily perhaps these prayers are known from their use in the Elemental Grades of the Golden Dawn... the idea is to empathise with the higher religious feelings of the spirits concerned, and thus attract them to you. This is a matter of attuning oneself to the spirits, encouraging them to trust and work with you, rather than of compulsion.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for practitioners seeking a deeper, more animistic engagement with spirits from grimoire traditions. It fills a significant gap by re-interpreting elements of the True Grimoire through an ancient lens, connecting it to Egyptian and Gnostic cosmologies. It moves beyond simplistic invocations, providing a framework for developing an ongoing, respectful alliance with elemental powers. The focus on Elelogap offers a practical entry point into water magic with tangible benefits for emotional and physical well-being, diverging from typical grimoire narratives centered on wealth or power.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes advanced students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Grimoire traditions, elemental magic, Gnosticism, and animist approaches to spirit work. It presumes a foundational understanding of occult concepts but guides the practitioner toward a more nuanced, relationship-focused practice. It is also valuable for scholars studying the historical continuity and syncretism within magical traditions.
